elements.content: For pure acetylene manufacturing and natural gas purification, the development of porous materials displaying highly selective C2H2/CH4 and CO2/CH4 separation is greatly important but remains a major challenge. In this work, a plausible strategy involving solvent-induced effects and using the flexibility of the ligand conformation to make two In­(III) metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is developed, showing topological diversity and different stability. The X-shaped tetracarboxylic ligand H4TPTA ([1,1′:3′,1″-terphenyl]-4,4′,4″,6′-tetracarboxylic acid) was selected to construct two new heteroid In MOFs, namely, {[CH3NH3]­[In­(TPTA)]·2­(NMF)} (MOF 1) and {[In2(TPTA)­(OH)2]·2­(H2O)·(DMF)} (MOF 2). MOF 1 is a (4, 4)-connected net showing a pts topology with a large channel that is not conducive to fine gas separation. By contrast, with the reduction of SBU from uninucleated In to an {In-OH-In} n chain, MOF 2 has a (4, 6)-connected net with the fsc topology with an ∼5 Å suitable micropore to confine matching small gas. The permanent porosity of MOF 2 leads to the preferential adsorption of C2H2 over CO2 with superior C2H2/CH4 (332.3) and CO2/CH4 (31.2) separation selectivities. Meanwhile, the cycling dynamic breakthrough experiments showed that the high-purity C2H2 (>99.8%) capture capacities of MOF 2 were >1.92 mmol g–1 from a binary C2H2/CH4 mixture, and its separation factor reached 10.

In this work, a plausible strategy involving solvent-induced effects and using the flexibility of the ligand conformation to make two In(III) metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is developed, showing topological diversity and different stability. The X-shaped tetracarboxylic ligand H4TPTA ([1,1':3',1"-terphenyl]-4,4',4",6'-tetracarboxylic acid) was selected to construct two new heteroid In MOFs, namely, {[CH3NH3][In(TPTA)]⋅2(NMF)} (MOF 1) and {[In2(TPTA)(OH)2]⋅2(H2O)⋅(DMF)} (MOF 2). MOF 1 is a (4, 4)-connected net showing a pts topology with a large channel that is not conducive to fine gas separation. By contrast, with the reduction of SBU from uninucleated In to an {In-OH-In} n  chain, MOF 2 has a (4, 6)-connected net with the fsc topology with an ~5 Å suitable micropore to confine matching small gas. The permanent porosity of MOF 2 leads to the preferential adsorption of C2H2 over CO2 with superior C2H2/CH4 (332.3) and CO2/CH4 (31.2) separation selectivities. Meanwhile, the cycling dynamic breakthrough experiments showed that the high-purity C2H2 (>99.8%) capture capacities of MOF 2 were >1.92 mmol g-1 from a binary C2H2/CH4 mixture, and its separation factor reached 10.

elements.content: Under the impact of solvent-induced effects, MOF 1 in the assembly of a monocluster with In and a tetracarboxylic ligand created a pts network structure with one-dimensional nanometer tube channels. MOF 2 belongs to an fsc network constructed with an infinite extended zigzag {In-OH-In} n chain as SBUs to build a micropore environment. Benefiting from the μ2-OH− groups and a 5.6 Å square hole with the potential to provide more suitable pore confinement effects, MOF 2 exhibits extraordinary selectivity of C2H2/CH4 and CO2/CH4. The outstanding reusability and high chemical stability make MOF 2 a promising candidate for the separation of these binary mixtures in practical applications.

Benefiting from the μ2-OH- groups and a 5.6 Å square hole with the potential to provide more suitable pore confinement effects, MOF 2 exhibits extraordinary selectivity of C2H2/CH4 and CO2/CH4. The outstanding reusability and high chemical stability make MOF 2 a promising candidate for the separation of these binary mixtures in practical applications.

elements.content: Clean energies such as natural gas, due to the increasingly serious environmental pollution caused by fossil energy, have attracted a great deal of attention worldwide. Natural gas is often accompanied by impurities such as carbon dioxide and C2-hydrocarbons. Therefore, to meet the requirements of natural gas pipeline specifications, it is essential that natural gas purification separate CH4 from CO2 and C2-hydrocarbons, which makes the search for effective separation adsorbents an important basic guarantee of industrial separation technology. In light of the cost-effectiveness and environmental compatibility, non-thermally driven separation and purification processes using porous materials have obvious advantages over those using traditional porous materials. Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), which consist of organic linkers and metal ions, have become strong competitors with their controllable structure and adjustable porosity, resulting in other potential applications, including gas sorbents, light-emitting sensors, catalysis, and optical and magnetic materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Clean energies such as natural gas, due to the increasingly serious environmental pollution caused by fossil energy, have attracted a great deal of attention worldwide. Natural gas is often accompanied by impurities such as carbon dioxide and C2-hydrocarbons. Therefore, to meet the requirements of natural gas pipeline specifications, it is essential that natural gas purification separate CH4 from CO2 and C2-hydrocarbons, which makes the search for effective separation adsorbents an important basic guarantee of industrial separation technology. In light of the cost-effectiveness and environmental compatibility, non-thermally driven separation and purification processes using porous materials have obvious advantages over those using traditional porous materials. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which consist of organic linkers and metal ions, have become strong competitors with their controllable structure and adjustable porosity, resulting in other potential applications, including gas sorbents, light-emitting sensors, catalysis, and optical and magnetic materials.

elements.content: On the basis of the engineering of the size and chemistry of the host framework, to improve the host–guest interaction, Lewis-based organic ligands (such as -NH2, -OH, and pyridine groups) are usually used as the main strategy for MOF material development for the separation and purification of gases. Another approach is to adjust the aperture of MOFs to reach the cutoff value that matches the size of the gas molecules, thus enhancing the separation screening effect and achieving higher selectivity. The precision of aperture adjustment can reach 0.1 Å. Therefore, the design of ultrafine pore MOFs with comparable pore sizes (many gas diameters in the range of 3–5 Å) has been greatly significant for the separation of small gas mixtures. Upon combination of the suitable pore confinement effects and binding functional site strategy, pore spaces in MOFs can even integrate shape matching and specific binding to target gas molecules. These directional MOFs are used to solve the puzzle of addressing the trade-off between a high adsorption capacity and a high selectivity. In addition, the structural diversity of porous MOFs, apart from the metal/ligand ratio, pH, temperature, and oxidation state of the metal ions, is also dependent on the solvent system in its template effect, generally believed to be one of the most significant factors, which can determine the crystallization process and the quality of the final product.

These directional MOFs are used to solve the puzzle of addressing the trade-off between a high adsorption capacity and a high selectivity. In addition, the structural diversity of porous MOFs, apart from the metal/ligand ratio, pH, temperature, and oxidation state of the metal ions, is also dependent on the solvent system in its template effect, generally believed to be one of the most significant factors, which can determine the crystallization process and the quality of the final product.

elements.content: In this work, an accessible approach was demonstrated by varying solvents to control the topology, pore integration shape, and pore chemistry environment of MOFs (), which impacted the adsorption and purification of gases. The X-shaped tetracarboxylic ligand H4TPTA ([1,1′:3′,1″-terphenyl]-4,4′,4″,6′-tetracarboxylic acid) was selected to construct two new heteroid In MOFs, namely, {[CH3NH3]­[In­(TPTA)]·2­(NMF)} (MOF 1) and {[In2(TPTA)­(OH)2]·2­(H2O)·(DMF)} (MOF 2). MOF 1 is a (4, 4)-connected net showing a pts topology with a large channel, and MOF 2 is a (4, 6)-connected net with an fsc topology with an ∼5 Å suitable micropore to confine matching small gas. Comparing the two separately in terms of their adsorption capabilities with respect to C2H2, CO2, C2H4, C2H6, and CH4 expounds upon their tunable performance for C2H2 refining applications, according to equilibrium/dynamic isotherm measurements in conjunction with separation selectivity assessment via an IAST (ideal adsorbed solution theory) model and the cycling dynamic breakthrough experiments. As a result, the stability, capacity in storage and separation, and binding affinity for the gas of MOF 2 are much better than those of MOF 1 due to the appropriate pore integration size and shape with action sites.

MOF 1 is a (4, 4)-connected net showing a pts topology with a large channel, and MOF 2 is a (4, 6)-connected net with an fsc topology with an ~5 Å suitable micropore to confine matching small gas. Comparing the two separately in terms of their adsorption capabilities with respect to C2H2, CO2, C2H4, C2H6, and CH4 expounds upon their tunable performance for C2H2 refining applications, according to equilibrium/dynamic isotherm measurements in conjunction with separation selectivity assessment via an IAST (ideal adsorbed solution theory) model and the cycling dynamic breakthrough experiments. As a result, the stability, capacity in storage and separation, and binding affinity for the gas of MOF 2 are much better than those of MOF 1 due to the appropriate pore integration size and shape with action sites.

elements.content: The chemicals used were obtained from ordinary sources, which can be used directly without re-treatment processes. MOF 1 was tested with reference to previously published methods. With accompanying Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) on a Rigaku D/max-2550 diffractometer, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were recorded. Then, by employing a TGA Q500 thermogravimetric analyzer, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed. Crystallographic data of MOF 2 were collected on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer by using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The comprehensive crystallization data of MOFs are listed in Table S1. Crystallographic data for MOF 1 (2086796) and MOF 2 (2154304) have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. Topology structure information about the compounds was calculated with TOPOS 4.0. The synthesized sample of MOF 2 was guest-exchanged frequently with MeOH for 3 days and then evacuated under dynamic vacuum at 373 K for 10 h to obtain the activated sample of the gas adsorption experiment by utilizing Autosorb iQ.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

The chemicals used were obtained from ordinary sources, which can be used directly without re-treatment processes. MOF 1 was tested with reference to previously published methods. With accompanying Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) on a Rigaku D/max-2550 diffractometer, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were recorded. Then, by employing a TGA Q500 thermogravimetric analyzer, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed. Crystallographic data of MOF 2 were collected on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer by using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The comprehensive crystallization data of MOFs are listed in Table S1. Crystallographic data for MOF 1 (2086796) and MOF 2 (2154304) have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. Topology structure information about the compounds was calculated with TOPOS 4.0. The synthesized sample of MOF 2 was guest-exchanged frequently with MeOH for 3 days and then evacuated under dynamic vacuum at 373 K for 10 h to obtain the activated sample of the gas adsorption experiment by utilizing Autosorb iQ.

elements.content:
MOF 1 can be prepared by the method described in the literature ().

Synthesis of MOF 2

The preparation of MOF 2 is similar to that of MOF 1 except that the NMF solvent (1.5 mL) was used instead of DMF and MOF 2 was made by combining In­(NO3)3·4H2O (8 mg, 0.021 mmol), H4TPTA (3 mg, 0.074 mmol), deionized water (H2O, 0.75 mL), and HNO3 (450 μL, 2.2 mL of HNO3 in 10 mL of DMF). Then, the mixture was placed in the precision oven reacting for 24 h at 120 °C. Colorless polyhedral solid crystals were collected in a yield of ∼53% (based on In). [In2(TPTA)­(OH)2]·2­(H2O)·(DMF) (wt %): C, 37.24; H, 2.23; N, 1.17. Calcd (wt %): C, 38.61; H, 2.96; N, 1.81.

Synthesis of MOF 1

Synthesis of MOF 2

The preparation of MOF 2 is similar to that of MOF 1 except that the NMF solvent (1.5 mL) was used instead of DMF and MOF 2 was made by combining In(NO3)3⋅4H2O (8 mg, 0.021 mmol), H4TPTA (3 mg, 0.074 mmol), deionized water (H2O, 0.75 mL), and HNO3 (450 μL, 2.2 mL of HNO3 in 10 mL of DMF). Then, the mixture was placed in the precision oven reacting for 24 h at 120 °C. Colorless polyhedral solid crystals were collected in a yield of ~53% (based on In). [In2(TPTA)(OH)2]⋅2(H2O)⋅(DMF) (wt %): C, 37.24; H, 2.23; N, 1.17. Calcd (wt %): C, 38.61; H, 2.96; N, 1.81.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that MOF 1 and MOF 2 belong to totally different crystal systems and space groups: MOF 1 in the tetragonal crystal system in the I41/amd space group and MOF 2 in the orthorhombic crystal system in the Pbcm space group (Table S1). Different crystal building systems were attributed to different coordination models and configurational differences in their ligands. For MOF 1, its asymmetric unit contained one indium atom, one H4TPTA ligand, and one [CH3NH3]+ equilibrium charge ion (). Each deprotonated ligand coordinated with four mononuclear indiums in a bimonodentate fashion, which simplified to quadrilateral. Each mononuclear indium linked to six carboxylic acid O atoms from four ligands to form a tetrahedral geometry. Overall, the periodic connection created in the manner described above created a pts network structure with the maximal hexagon channel with a large pore window size of 18.1 Å × 16.6 Å viewed along the y axis (Figure S3). The Schlafli symbol is {42.84} in this (4, 4)-connected network. According to the calculation of PLATON software, the volume void rate reached 74.5% and the theoretical pore volume is 1.2 cm3 g–1.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Descriptions of MOF 1 and MOF 2

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that MOF 1 and MOF 2 belong to totally different crystal systems and space groups: MOF 1 in the tetragonal crystal system in the I41/amd space group and MOF 2 in the orthorhombic crystal system in the Pbcm space group (Table S1). Different crystal building systems were attributed to different coordination models and configurational differences in their ligands. For MOF 1, its asymmetric unit contained one indium atom, one H4TPTA ligand, and one [CH3NH3]+ equilibrium charge ion (). Each deprotonated ligand coordinated with four mononuclear indiums in a bimonodentate fashion, which simplified to quadrilateral. Each mononuclear indium linked to six carboxylic acid O atoms from four ligands to form a tetrahedral geometry. Overall, the periodic connection created in the manner described above created a pts network structure with the maximal hexagon channel with a large pore window size of 18.1 Å × 16.6 Å viewed along the y axis (Figure S3). The Schlafli symbol is {42.84} in this (4, 4)-connected network. According to the calculation of PLATON software, the volume void rate reached 74.5% and the theoretical pore volume is 1.2 cm3 g-1.

elements.content: Coordination modes of the ligand (H4TPTA) and assembly procedure of structurally different MOF 1 and MOF 2 that show pts and fsc net topologies, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 2  Coordination modes of the ligand (H4TPTA) and assembly procedure of structurally different MOF 1 and MOF 2 that show pts and fsc net topologies, respectively.

elements.content: As for MOF 2, the asymmetric unit was collected with one H4TPTA ligand, two In3+ions, and two μ2-OH– groups, and then each In3+ ion was also attached with six O atoms from four different ligands and two μ2-OH– groups, regarded as an octahedral coordination geometry [In–O, 2.086(2)–2.197(2) Å]. Considering the appropriate spatial tension, the ligand of MOF 1 uses a slight twist of ∼4° to facilitate the assembly of the hexagonal mesh while MOF 2 coordinates the formation of octahedral indium coordination with an opening angle of 36° (a,d). Following the connection described above, the In3+ ions and four ligands propped up 4-connected planar square lattice layers, and then through bridging, oxygens of μ2-OH– groups contacted repetitive In3+ ions unit to arrange an infinite extended zigzag {In-OH-In} n chain, like a pillar (Figure S4), which can be regarded as a pillared-layer strategy. As a whole, the layer combined with the pillar zigzag chains to generate a typical three-dimensional fsc framework with multiple 1D open channels: along the x axis direction rhombic channels with pore sizes of 6.3 Å × 5.6 Å and along the z axis direction rectangular channels with pore sizes of 3.8 Å × 4.2 Å (including the van der Waals radii). From the analysis of topology, the H4TPTA ligand can be regarded as a 4-connected node, and In–OH–In clusters as a 6-connected node, falling within the fsc topology with a Schlafli symbol of {44.610.8}­{44.62} (e). According to the calculation of PLATON, the theoretical volume void rate reached 47.0%.

Considering the appropriate spatial tension, the ligand of MOF 1 uses a slight twist of ~4° to facilitate the assembly of the hexagonal mesh while MOF 2 coordinates the formation of octahedral indium coordination with an opening angle of 36° (a,d). Following the connection described above, the In3+ ions and four ligands propped up 4-connected planar square lattice layers, and then through bridging, oxygens of μ2-OH- groups contacted repetitive In3+ ions unit to arrange an infinite extended zigzag {In-OH-In} n  chain, like a pillar (Figure S4), which can be regarded as a pillared-layer strategy. As a whole, the layer combined with the pillar zigzag chains to generate a typical three-dimensional fsc framework with multiple 1D open channels: along the x axis direction rhombic channels with pore sizes of 6.3 Å × 5.6 Å and along the z axis direction rectangular channels with pore sizes of 3.8 Å × 4.2 Å (including the van der Waals radii). From the analysis of topology, the H4TPTA ligand can be regarded as a 4-connected node, and In-OH-In clusters as a 6-connected node, falling within the fsc topology with a Schlafli symbol of {44.610.8}{44.62} (e). According to the calculation of PLATON, the theoretical volume void rate reached 47.0%.

elements.content: The consistency of the experiment and analogous PXRD patterns indicated crystal products MOF 1 and MOF 2 with phase purity. The related basic characterization of MOF 1 was described previously. MOF 1 can retain its original structure in some organic solvents, but it is destroyed in water (Figure S1b). However, it has been confirmed by PXRD patterns that the crystallinity of MOF 2 can remain unchanged after immersion in aqueous HCl or NaOH solutions with pH values in the range of 3–12, showing high chemical stability (Figure S1d), which may be attributed to the stable indium cluster. Additionally, as shown in Figure S2, TGA of MOF 2 reveals that there are mainly two steps of weightlessness. The first step is ∼14.4%, corresponding to the loss of solvent molecules (calculated as one DMF molecule and two water molecules). The second step is close to 36.7%, owing to the slow destruction of the skeleton when the temperature is >450 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization of MOF 1 and MOF 2

The consistency of the experiment and analogous PXRD patterns indicated crystal products MOF 1 and MOF 2 with phase purity. The related basic characterization of MOF 1 was described previously. MOF 1 can retain its original structure in some organic solvents, but it is destroyed in water (Figure S1b). However, it has been confirmed by PXRD patterns that the crystallinity of MOF 2 can remain unchanged after immersion in aqueous HCl or NaOH solutions with pH values in the range of 3-12, showing high chemical stability (Figure S1d), which may be attributed to the stable indium cluster. Additionally, as shown in Figure S2, TGA of MOF 2 reveals that there are mainly two steps of weightlessness. The first step is ~14.4%, corresponding to the loss of solvent molecules (calculated as one DMF molecule and two water molecules). The second step is close to 36.7%, owing to the slow destruction of the skeleton when the temperature is >450 °C.

elements.content: Considering the structural characteristics of MOF 1 and MOF 2 both with multiple channels, the pore properties and gas adsorption performance of these two MOFs were investigated. Unexpectedly, MOF 1 has negligible N2 adsorption at 77 K (uptake of approximately 28 cm3 g–1 and BET of just 55 m2 g–1). Moreover, at 195 K, the adsorption curves showed CO2 uptake of MOF 1 of only 20 cm3 g–1 at 100 kPa, corroborating weak interactions of CO2 (Figure S6a). As shown in Figure S6b, its crystallinity remains unchanged after the adsorption of CO2 at 195 K and N2 at 77 K, resulting in MOF 1 having low adsorption capacity that was not for structural collapse or shrinkage. This can also be demonstrated by other MOFs, such as [(CH3)2NH2]­[In­(BDCPPI)]·0.5DMF·H2O and JUC-210 with similar adsorption behaviors. By contrast, the N2 adsorption of MOF 2 at 77 K exhibited a typical reversible type I curve feature, with a maximum adsorption amount of N2 uptake of ∼205 cm3 g–1 (). The relevant specific surface areas of BET and Langmuir are 631 and 658 m2 g–1, respectively. Furthermore, the pore size distributions of MOF 2 utilizing the DFT method reveal the presence of pore sizes centered at 5.6 and 7.8 Å. In terms of the crystal structures of MOF 2, its pore volumes are calculated by PLATON to reach 0.35 cm3 g–1. This corresponded well with the pore volumes experimentally estimated on the basis of the N2 adsorption isotherms (0.3 cm3 g–1). Finally, the PXRD pattern of MOF 1 and MOF 2 after N2 gas adsorption retained the same crystallinity as the simulated form and their structures are still intact (Figure S6).
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption of MOF 1 and MOF 2

Considering the structural characteristics of MOF 1 and MOF 2 both with multiple channels, the pore properties and gas adsorption performance of these two MOFs were investigated. Unexpectedly, MOF 1 has negligible N2 adsorption at 77 K (uptake of approximately 28 cm3 g-1 and BET of just 55 m2 g-1). Moreover, at 195 K, the adsorption curves showed CO2 uptake of MOF 1 of only 20 cm3 g-1 at 100 kPa, corroborating weak interactions of CO2 (Figure S6a). As shown in Figure S6b, its crystallinity remains unchanged after the adsorption of CO2 at 195 K and N2 at 77 K, resulting in MOF 1 having low adsorption capacity that was not for structural collapse or shrinkage. This can also be demonstrated by other MOFs, such as [(CH3)2NH2][In(BDCPPI)]⋅0.5DMF⋅H2O and JUC-210 with similar adsorption behaviors. By contrast, the N2 adsorption of MOF 2 at 77 K exhibited a typical reversible type I curve feature, with a maximum adsorption amount of N2 uptake of ~205 cm3 g-1 (). The relevant specific surface areas of BET and Langmuir are 631 and 658 m2 g-1, respectively. Furthermore, the pore size distributions of MOF 2 utilizing the DFT method reveal the presence of pore sizes centered at 5.6 and 7.8 Å. In terms of the crystal structures of MOF 2, its pore volumes are calculated by PLATON to reach 0.35 cm3 g-1. This corresponded well with the pore volumes experimentally estimated on the basis of the N2 adsorption isotherms (0.3 cm3 g-1). Finally, the PXRD pattern of MOF 1 and MOF 2 after N2 gas adsorption retained the same crystallinity as the simulated form and their structures are still intact (Figure S6).

elements.content: To further study the potential applications of MOF 1 and MOF 2 for gas capture and separation with different sizes or properties, the single-component gas adsorption isotherms of CO2, CH4, C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 were recorded (). For the case of MOF 1, the gas adsorption capacities of CO2 are only 21 and 15 cm3 g–1, those of CH4 9.9 and 6.0 cm3 g–1, those of C2H2 33 and 24 cm3 g–1, those of C2H4 21 and 15 cm3 g–1, and those of C2H6 17 and 11 cm3 g–1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively. By comparison, MOF 2 was found to exhibit excellent storage capacity and obviously selective adsorption properties. At 273 and 298 K under 1 atm, it takes up 49 and 33 cm3 g–1 of CO2, 14 and 4 cm3 g–1 of CH4, 108 and 78 cm3 g–1 of C2H2, 53 and 39 cm3 g–1 of C2H4, and 63 and 39 cm3 g–1 of C2H6, respectively. From the structural analysis, MOF 2 with a smaller pore and larger specific surface area has more adsorption potential than does MOF 1. Compared to those of MOF 1, the high adsorption performances of MOF 2 are attributed to the existence of μ2-OH– groups in the channel of the infinite extended {In-OH-In} n chain, so they are conducive to the formation of guest–host or guest–guest interactions between sorbent and gas molecules. More importantly, a 5.6 Å square hole of MOF 2 may offer the potential to provide more suitable pore confinement effects, while MOF 1 has a large one-dimensional pore space (pore sizes of ∼18.1 Å × ∼16.6 Å and ∼13.9 Å × ∼8.2 Å) that is not good for gas separation. Such a systematic difference in uptake capacity illustrates the potential of MOF 2 in the separation of flue gas and hydrocarbon mixtures under ambient conditions. Furthermore, C2H2 adsorption on MOF 2 was carried out five times at 298 K, and their maximum uptakes are close to that of the pristine sample, which confirmed its stability and reproducibility (Figure S6c,d). It can be stable after gas cycling and can maintain the integrity of crystallinity in air.

More importantly, a 5.6 Å square hole of MOF 2 may offer the potential to provide more suitable pore confinement effects, while MOF 1 has a large one-dimensional pore space (pore sizes of ~18.1 Å × ~16.6 Å and ~13.9 Å × ~8.2 Å) that is not good for gas separation. Such a systematic difference in uptake capacity illustrates the potential of MOF 2 in the separation of flue gas and hydrocarbon mixtures under ambient conditions. Furthermore, C2H2 adsorption on MOF 2 was carried out five times at 298 K, and their maximum uptakes are close to that of the pristine sample, which confirmed its stability and reproducibility (Figure S6c,d). It can be stable after gas cycling and can maintain the integrity of crystallinity in air.

elements.content: To gauge the binding affinity of the framework–gas interaction, the Q st values were calculated using the Clausius–Clapeyron equation applied to the single-component gas adsorption isotherms (f and Figure S5). At zero coverage, the Q st values of C2H2, CO2, and CH4 for MOF 1 are determined to be 45.7, 33.4, and 10.6 kJ mol–1, respectively. For MOF 2, the Q st values of C2H2, CO2, and CH4 are 49.8, 33.0, and 17.0 kJ mol–1, respectively. Compared with MOF 1, active O sites and pore size matching regulated by a one-dimensional chain slightly increased Q st values for MOF 2, which are consistent with the higher adsorption at low pressure and higher selectivity, indicating a stronger affinity for MOF 2 and gas. Among the rest, the Q st of C2H2 for MOF 2 (49.8 kJ mol–1) is much higher than the other values reported for In-based MOFs, such as [In2(L)­(OH)2]·2DMF·2H2O (32 kJ mol–1), BUT-70B (27 kJ mol–1), and ZJNU-115 (29 kJ mol–1). It manifests that the smaller pore size results in the reinforced overlapped potential for C2H2 adsorption. Notably, huge discrepancies between Q st values for C2H2 and CH4 suggest that MOF 2 will promise good performance for C2H2/CH4 separation.

elements.content: To estimate the selective adsorption capacity of MOF 2 with binary gas molecules, the industrial separation simulation was carried out via well-defined ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST). As shown in Table S4 and , the levels of uptake of C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 (C2 light hydrocarbon) by MOF 2 are much higher than that of CH4 (0.2 mmol g–1), reaching 3.5, 1.7, and 1.8 mmol g–1, respectively, at 1 kPa. The simulated adsorption selectivities (S ads) for the 50/50 C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, and C2H6/CH4 binary equimolar mixtures are 332, 76, and 89, respectively. Exactly as in b, in particular, the S ads (C2H2/CH4 of 332) of MOF 2 at 298 K, close to that of ZJU-198a (391), has exceeded those observed in other MOFs such as Zr-SDBA (230), NbU-11 (175), CuDTTA (166), UTSA-50 (68), and PCM-48 (<25) as shown in a. These results indicate the potential adsorbent in the practical petroleum industry for C2/C1 light hydrocarbon separation. Beyond that, the simulated adsorption selectivities of C2H2/C2H4 and C2H2/C2H6 are 3.9 and 2.2, respectively, where the pore size effect and similar polarizability lead to co-adsorption of C2H2 with C2H6 and C2H4.

elements.content: In addition, the CO2 loadings reached ∼1.6 mmol g–1 and the selectivity of the C2H2/CO2 binary combinations is 5.7, while encouragingly, that of CO2/CH4 (31) is higher than those of Ni-MOF-74 (29), SNNU-14 (19), FJU-44a (16), JLU-Liu66 (9.4), and NOTT-125 (4.8), which promotes MOF 2 as a hopeful CO2 adsorbent from depurinating biogas and flue gas mixtures (b). The high selectivity of C2H2/CH4 and CO2/CH4 can be attributed to the following. On one hand, the appropriate hole size has good size-sieving performance obtained with an increase in pressure, with regard to gas molecules of different sizes and shapes. On the other hand, the high concentration of active sites in the pore surface enhances the interactions between the framework and CO2 and C2H2 molecules containing unsaturated bonds. Moreover, CH4 has the lowest absorption capacity and the weakest interaction is probably determined by the lower molecular polarizabilities of CH4. Hence, the synergistic effect promotes MOF 2 as a promising ideal adsorbent material for application in selectivity for CO2/CH4 and C2H2/CH4.

elements.content: To evaluate the feasibility of MOF 2 for selective C2H2/CH4 and CO2/CH4 separation, transient breakthrough experiments were performed in fixed-bed adsorption processes with a 1/1 gas mixture flowing at a rate of 2.0 mL min–1 through a packed column with 0.557 g of as-activated MOF 2. For C2H2/CH4 separation, as shown in a, C2H2 remained in the column longer than CH4 did, with the retention times recorded as 21.6 min g–1 for CH4 and 57.5 min g–1 for C2H2. The dynamic high-purity C2H2 (>99.8%) capture capacity of MOF 2 can reach 1.93 mmol g–1, and that for CH4 0.20 mmol g–1, thus giving a separation factor of 10. Similar results can also be observed for the CO2/CH4 mixture (b); from the column outlet, CH4 was initially detected and quickly approached pure grade (29.9 min g–1), whereas CO2 was captured by the packed samples until breakthrough (37.3 min g–1) with a separation factor of 2. To ensure the excellent cycle performance and easy regeneration of MOF 2, multiple cycling dynamic breakthrough experiments were performed accordingly. In panels c and d of , the C2H2 capture capacities and separation performances demonstrated by cycling experiments remain steady after several cycles, further demonstrating that MOF 2 is a potential adsorbent for C2H2 separation and capture.

elements.content: In summary, a pair of isomers of In­(III)-based MOFs can be directionally fabricated by rationally tuning the solvent environment, which adjusts the aperture and immobilizes of OH sites in a prototype MOF for C2H2/CH4 and CO2/CH4 separation. MOF 1 and MOF 2 have the same 4-connected organic linkers but adopt uninucleated In and the {In-OH-In} n chain as secondary building units, forming networks with pts and fsc topologies, respectively, which derive from the conformational flexibility of the organic ligands. In terms of gas separation performance, MOF 1 with a large pore size is not conducive to fine gas separation. By contrast, with a decrease in pore size and the effect of adsorption sites, MOF 2 with its permanent porosity demonstrates preferential C2H2 over CO2 adsorption and superior C2H2/CH4 and CO2/CH4 separation selectivities, which show the strong affinity of MOF 2 for gas molecules. The outstanding chemical stability and good reusability make MOF 2 a promising candidate for the separation of these binary mixtures in practical applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a pair of isomers of In(III)-based MOFs can be directionally fabricated by rationally tuning the solvent environment, which adjusts the aperture and immobilizes of OH sites in a prototype MOF for C2H2/CH4 and CO2/CH4 separation. MOF 1 and MOF 2 have the same 4-connected organic linkers but adopt uninucleated In and the {In-OH-In} n  chain as secondary building units, forming networks with pts and fsc topologies, respectively, which derive from the conformational flexibility of the organic ligands. In terms of gas separation performance, MOF 1 with a large pore size is not conducive to fine gas separation. By contrast, with a decrease in pore size and the effect of adsorption sites, MOF 2 with its permanent porosity demonstrates preferential C2H2 over CO2 adsorption and superior C2H2/CH4 and CO2/CH4 separation selectivities, which show the strong affinity of MOF 2 for gas molecules. The outstanding chemical stability and good reusability make MOF 2 a promising candidate for the separation of these binary mixtures in practical applications.

MOF 1 can be prepared by the method described in the literature ().

Synthesis of MOF 2

The preparation of MOF 2 is similar to that of MOF 1 except that the NMF solvent (1.5 mL) was used instead of DMF and MOF 2 was made by combining In­(NO3)3·4H2O (8 mg, 0.021 mmol), H4TPTA (3 mg, 0.074 mmol), deionized water (H2O, 0.75 mL), and HNO3 (450 μL, 2.2 mL of HNO3 in 10 mL of DMF). Then, the mixture was placed in the precision oven reacting for 24 h at 120 °C. Colorless polyhedral solid crystals were collected in a yield of ∼53% (based on In). [In2(TPTA)­(OH)2]·2­(H2O)·(DMF) (wt %): C, 37.24; H, 2.23; N, 1.17. Calcd (wt %): C, 38.61; H, 2.96; N, 1.81.

cln_elements.content:
For pure acetylene manufacturing and natural gas purification, the development of porous materials displaying highly selective C2H2/CH4 and CO2/CH4 separation is greatly important but remains a major challenge. In this work, a plausible strategy involving solvent-induced effects and using the flexibility of the ligand conformation to make two In­(III) metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is developed, showing topological diversity and different stability. The X-shaped tetracarboxylic ligand H4TPTA ([1,1′:3′,1″-terphenyl]-4,4′,4″,6′-tetracarboxylic acid) was selected to construct two new heteroid In MOFs, namely, {[CH3NH3]­[In­(TPTA)]·2­(NMF)} (MOF 1) and {[In2(TPTA)­(OH)2]·2­(H2O)·(DMF)} (MOF 2). MOF 1 is a (4, 4)-connected net showing a pts topology with a large channel that is not conducive to fine gas separation. By contrast, with the reduction of SBU from uninucleated In to an {In-OH-In} n chain, MOF 2 has a (4, 6)-connected net with the fsc topology with an ∼5 Å suitable micropore to confine matching small gas. The permanent porosity of MOF 2 leads to the preferential adsorption of C2H2 over CO2 with superior C2H2/CH4 (332.3) and CO2/CH4 (31.2) separation selectivities. Meanwhile, the cycling dynamic breakthrough experiments showed that the high-purity C2H2 (>99.8%) capture capacities of MOF 2 were >1.92 mmol g–1 from a binary C2H2/CH4 mixture, and its separation factor reached 10.

Results and DiscussionStructural Descriptions of MOF 1 and MOF 2

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that MOF 1 and MOF 2 belong to totally different crystal systems and space groups: MOF 1 in the tetragonal crystal system in the I41/amd space group and MOF 2 in the orthorhombic crystal system in the Pbcm space group (Table S1). Different crystal building systems were attributed to different coordination models and configurational differences in their ligands. For MOF 1, its asymmetric unit contained one indium atom, one H4TPTA ligand, and one [CH3NH3]+ equilibrium charge ion (). Each deprotonated ligand coordinated with four mononuclear indiums in a bimonodentate fashion, which simplified to quadrilateral. Each mononuclear indium linked to six carboxylic acid O atoms from four ligands to form a tetrahedral geometry. Overall, the periodic connection created in the manner described above created a pts network structure with the maximal hexagon channel with a large pore window size of 18.1 Å × 16.6 Å viewed along the y axis (Figure S3). The Schlafli symbol is {42.84} in this (4, 4)-connected network. According to the calculation of PLATON software, the volume void rate reached 74.5% and the theoretical pore volume is 1.2 cm3 g–1.

Characterization of MOF 1 and MOF 2

The consistency of the experiment and analogous PXRD patterns indicated crystal products MOF 1 and MOF 2 with phase purity. The related basic characterization of MOF 1 was described previously. MOF 1 can retain its original structure in some organic solvents, but it is destroyed in water (Figure S1b). However, it has been confirmed by PXRD patterns that the crystallinity of MOF 2 can remain unchanged after immersion in aqueous HCl or NaOH solutions with pH values in the range of 3–12, showing high chemical stability (Figure S1d), which may be attributed to the stable indium cluster. Additionally, as shown in Figure S2, TGA of MOF 2 reveals that there are mainly two steps of weightlessness. The first step is ∼14.4%, corresponding to the loss of solvent molecules (calculated as one DMF molecule and two water molecules). The second step is close to 36.7%, owing to the slow destruction of the skeleton when the temperature is >450 °C.

Gas Adsorption of MOF 1 and MOF 2

Considering the structural characteristics of MOF 1 and MOF 2 both with multiple channels, the pore properties and gas adsorption performance of these two MOFs were investigated. Unexpectedly, MOF 1 has negligible N2 adsorption at 77 K (uptake of approximately 28 cm3 g–1 and BET of just 55 m2 g–1). Moreover, at 195 K, the adsorption curves showed CO2 uptake of MOF 1 of only 20 cm3 g–1 at 100 kPa, corroborating weak interactions of CO2 (Figure S6a). As shown in Figure S6b, its crystallinity remains unchanged after the adsorption of CO2 at 195 K and N2 at 77 K, resulting in MOF 1 having low adsorption capacity that was not for structural collapse or shrinkage. This can also be demonstrated by other MOFs, such as [(CH3)2NH2]­[In­(BDCPPI)]·0.5DMF·H2O and JUC-210 with similar adsorption behaviors. By contrast, the N2 adsorption of MOF 2 at 77 K exhibited a typical reversible type I curve feature, with a maximum adsorption amount of N2 uptake of ∼205 cm3 g–1 (). The relevant specific surface areas of BET and Langmuir are 631 and 658 m2 g–1, respectively. Furthermore, the pore size distributions of MOF 2 utilizing the DFT method reveal the presence of pore sizes centered at 5.6 and 7.8 Å. In terms of the crystal structures of MOF 2, its pore volumes are calculated by PLATON to reach 0.35 cm3 g–1. This corresponded well with the pore volumes experimentally estimated on the basis of the N2 adsorption isotherms (0.3 cm3 g–1). Finally, the PXRD pattern of MOF 1 and MOF 2 after N2 gas adsorption retained the same crystallinity as the simulated form and their structures are still intact (Figure S6).

To further study the potential applications of MOF 1 and MOF 2 for gas capture and separation with different sizes or properties, the single-component gas adsorption isotherms of CO2, CH4, C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 were recorded (). For the case of MOF 1, the gas adsorption capacities of CO2 are only 21 and 15 cm3 g–1, those of CH4 9.9 and 6.0 cm3 g–1, those of C2H2 33 and 24 cm3 g–1, those of C2H4 21 and 15 cm3 g–1, and those of C2H6 17 and 11 cm3 g–1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively. By comparison, MOF 2 was found to exhibit excellent storage capacity and obviously selective adsorption properties. At 273 and 298 K under 1 atm, it takes up 49 and 33 cm3 g–1 of CO2, 14 and 4 cm3 g–1 of CH4, 108 and 78 cm3 g–1 of C2H2, 53 and 39 cm3 g–1 of C2H4, and 63 and 39 cm3 g–1 of C2H6, respectively. From the structural analysis, MOF 2 with a smaller pore and larger specific surface area has more adsorption potential than does MOF 1. Compared to those of MOF 1, the high adsorption performances of MOF 2 are attributed to the existence of μ2-OH– groups in the channel of the infinite extended {In-OH-In} n chain, so they are conducive to the formation of guest–host or guest–guest interactions between sorbent and gas molecules. More importantly, a 5.6 Å square hole of MOF 2 may offer the potential to provide more suitable pore confinement effects, while MOF 1 has a large one-dimensional pore space (pore sizes of ∼18.1 Å × ∼16.6 Å and ∼13.9 Å × ∼8.2 Å) that is not good for gas separation. Such a systematic difference in uptake capacity illustrates the potential of MOF 2 in the separation of flue gas and hydrocarbon mixtures under ambient conditions. Furthermore, C2H2 adsorption on MOF 2 was carried out five times at 298 K, and their maximum uptakes are close to that of the pristine sample, which confirmed its stability and reproducibility (Figure S6c,d). It can be stable after gas cycling and can maintain the integrity of crystallinity in air.

To gauge the binding affinity of the framework–gas interaction, the Q st values were calculated using the Clausius–Clapeyron equation applied to the single-component gas adsorption isotherms (f and Figure S5). At zero coverage, the Q st values of C2H2, CO2, and CH4 for MOF 1 are determined to be 45.7, 33.4, and 10.6 kJ mol–1, respectively. For MOF 2, the Q st values of C2H2, CO2, and CH4 are 49.8, 33.0, and 17.0 kJ mol–1, respectively. Compared with MOF 1, active O sites and pore size matching regulated by a one-dimensional chain slightly increased Q st values for MOF 2, which are consistent with the higher adsorption at low pressure and higher selectivity, indicating a stronger affinity for MOF 2 and gas. Among the rest, the Q st of C2H2 for MOF 2 (49.8 kJ mol–1) is much higher than the other values reported for In-based MOFs, such as [In2(L)­(OH)2]·2DMF·2H2O (32 kJ mol–1), BUT-70B (27 kJ mol–1), and ZJNU-115 (29 kJ mol–1). It manifests that the smaller pore size results in the reinforced overlapped potential for C2H2 adsorption. Notably, huge discrepancies between Q st values for C2H2 and CH4 suggest that MOF 2 will promise good performance for C2H2/CH4 separation.

Overall, the periodic connection created in the manner described above created a pts network structure with the maximal hexagon channel with a large pore window size of 18.1 Å × 16.6 Å viewed along the y axis (Figure S3). The Schlafli symbol is {42.84} in this (4, 4)-connected network. According to the calculation of PLATON software, the volume void rate reached 74.5% and the theoretical pore volume is 1.2 cm3 g-1.

Characterization of MOF 1 and MOF 2

The consistency of the experiment and analogous PXRD patterns indicated crystal products MOF 1 and MOF 2 with phase purity. The related basic characterization of MOF 1 was described previously. MOF 1 can retain its original structure in some organic solvents, but it is destroyed in water (Figure S1b). However, it has been confirmed by PXRD patterns that the crystallinity of MOF 2 can remain unchanged after immersion in aqueous HCl or NaOH solutions with pH values in the range of 3-12, showing high chemical stability (Figure S1d), which may be attributed to the stable indium cluster. Additionally, as shown in Figure S2, TGA of MOF 2 reveals that there are mainly two steps of weightlessness. The first step is ~14.4%, corresponding to the loss of solvent molecules (calculated as one DMF molecule and two water molecules). The second step is close to 36.7%, owing to the slow destruction of the skeleton when the temperature is >450 °C.

Gas Adsorption of MOF 1 and MOF 2

Considering the structural characteristics of MOF 1 and MOF 2 both with multiple channels, the pore properties and gas adsorption performance of these two MOFs were investigated. Unexpectedly, MOF 1 has negligible N2 adsorption at 77 K (uptake of approximately 28 cm3 g-1 and BET of just 55 m2 g-1). Moreover, at 195 K, the adsorption curves showed CO2 uptake of MOF 1 of only 20 cm3 g-1 at 100 kPa, corroborating weak interactions of CO2 (Figure S6a). As shown in Figure S6b, its crystallinity remains unchanged after the adsorption of CO2 at 195 K and N2 at 77 K, resulting in MOF 1 having low adsorption capacity that was not for structural collapse or shrinkage. This can also be demonstrated by other MOFs, such as [(CH3)2NH2][In(BDCPPI)]⋅0.5DMF⋅H2O and JUC-210 with similar adsorption behaviors. By contrast, the N2 adsorption of MOF 2 at 77 K exhibited a typical reversible type I curve feature, with a maximum adsorption amount of N2 uptake of ~205 cm3 g-1 (). The relevant specific surface areas of BET and Langmuir are 631 and 658 m2 g-1, respectively. Furthermore, the pore size distributions of MOF 2 utilizing the DFT method reveal the presence of pore sizes centered at 5.6 and 7.8 Å. In terms of the crystal structures of MOF 2, its pore volumes are calculated by PLATON to reach 0.35 cm3 g-1. This corresponded well with the pore volumes experimentally estimated on the basis of the N2 adsorption isotherms (0.3 cm3 g-1). Finally, the PXRD pattern of MOF 1 and MOF 2 after N2 gas adsorption retained the same crystallinity as the simulated form and their structures are still intact (Figure S6).

To further study the potential applications of MOF 1 and MOF 2 for gas capture and separation with different sizes or properties, the single-component gas adsorption isotherms of CO2, CH4, C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 were recorded (). For the case of MOF 1, the gas adsorption capacities of CO2 are only 21 and 15 cm3 g-1, those of CH4 9.9 and 6.0 cm3 g-1, those of C2H2 33 and 24 cm3 g-1, those of C2H4 21 and 15 cm3 g-1, and those of C2H6 17 and 11 cm3 g-1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively. By comparison, MOF 2 was found to exhibit excellent storage capacity and obviously selective adsorption properties. At 273 and 298 K under 1 atm, it takes up 49 and 33 cm3 g-1 of CO2, 14 and 4 cm3 g-1 of CH4, 108 and 78 cm3 g-1 of C2H2, 53 and 39 cm3 g-1 of C2H4, and 63 and 39 cm3 g-1 of C2H6, respectively. From the structural analysis, MOF 2 with a smaller pore and larger specific surface area has more adsorption potential than does MOF 1. Compared to those of MOF 1, the high adsorption performances of MOF 2 are attributed to the existence of μ2-OH- groups in the channel of the infinite extended {In-OH-In} n  chain, so they are conducive to the formation of guest-host or guest-guest interactions between sorbent and gas molecules. More importantly, a 5.6 Å square hole of MOF 2 may offer the potential to provide more suitable pore confinement effects, while MOF 1 has a large one-dimensional pore space (pore sizes of ~18.1 Å × ~16.6 Å and ~13.9 Å × ~8.2 Å) that is not good for gas separation. Such a systematic difference in uptake capacity illustrates the potential of MOF 2 in the separation of flue gas and hydrocarbon mixtures under ambient conditions. Furthermore, C2H2 adsorption on MOF 2 was carried out five times at 298 K, and their maximum uptakes are close to that of the pristine sample, which confirmed its stability and reproducibility (Figure S6c,d). It can be stable after gas cycling and can maintain the integrity of crystallinity in air.

To gauge the binding affinity of the framework-gas interaction, the Q st values were calculated using the Clausius-Clapeyron equation applied to the single-component gas adsorption isotherms (f and Figure S5). At zero coverage, the Q st values of C2H2, CO2, and CH4 for MOF 1 are determined to be 45.7, 33.4, and 10.6 kJ mol-1, respectively. For MOF 2, the Q st values of C2H2, CO2, and CH4 are 49.8, 33.0, and 17.0 kJ mol-1, respectively. Compared with MOF 1, active O sites and pore size matching regulated by a one-dimensional chain slightly increased Q st values for MOF 2, which are consistent with the higher adsorption at low pressure and higher selectivity, indicating a stronger affinity for MOF 2 and gas. Among the rest, the Q st of C2H2 for MOF 2 (49.8 kJ mol-1) is much higher than the other values reported for In-based MOFs, such as [In2(L)(OH)2]⋅2DMF⋅2H2O (32 kJ mol-1), BUT-70B (27 kJ mol-1), and ZJNU-115 (29 kJ mol-1). It manifests that the smaller pore size results in the reinforced overlapped potential for C2H2 adsorption. Notably, huge discrepancies between Q st values for C2H2 and CH4 suggest that MOF 2 will promise good performance for C2H2/CH4 separation.

cln_elements.content:
To estimate the selective adsorption capacity of MOF 2 with binary gas molecules, the industrial separation simulation was carried out via well-defined ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST). As shown in Table S4 and , the levels of uptake of C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 (C2 light hydrocarbon) by MOF 2 are much higher than that of CH4 (0.2 mmol g–1), reaching 3.5, 1.7, and 1.8 mmol g–1, respectively, at 1 kPa. The simulated adsorption selectivities (S ads) for the 50/50 C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, and C2H6/CH4 binary equimolar mixtures are 332, 76, and 89, respectively. Exactly as in b, in particular, the S ads (C2H2/CH4 of 332) of MOF 2 at 298 K, close to that of ZJU-198a (391), has exceeded those observed in other MOFs such as Zr-SDBA (230), NbU-11 (175), CuDTTA (166), UTSA-50 (68), and PCM-48 (<25) as shown in a. These results indicate the potential adsorbent in the practical petroleum industry for C2/C1 light hydrocarbon separation. Beyond that, the simulated adsorption selectivities of C2H2/C2H4 and C2H2/C2H6 are 3.9 and 2.2, respectively, where the pore size effect and similar polarizability lead to co-adsorption of C2H2 with C2H6 and C2H4.

In addition, the CO2 loadings reached ∼1.6 mmol g–1 and the selectivity of the C2H2/CO2 binary combinations is 5.7, while encouragingly, that of CO2/CH4 (31) is higher than those of Ni-MOF-74 (29), SNNU-14 (19), FJU-44a (16), JLU-Liu66 (9.4), and NOTT-125 (4.8), which promotes MOF 2 as a hopeful CO2 adsorbent from depurinating biogas and flue gas mixtures (b). The high selectivity of C2H2/CH4 and CO2/CH4 can be attributed to the following. On one hand, the appropriate hole size has good size-sieving performance obtained with an increase in pressure, with regard to gas molecules of different sizes and shapes. On the other hand, the high concentration of active sites in the pore surface enhances the interactions between the framework and CO2 and C2H2 molecules containing unsaturated bonds. Moreover, CH4 has the lowest absorption capacity and the weakest interaction is probably determined by the lower molecular polarizabilities of CH4. Hence, the synergistic effect promotes MOF 2 as a promising ideal adsorbent material for application in selectivity for CO2/CH4 and C2H2/CH4.

To evaluate the feasibility of MOF 2 for selective C2H2/CH4 and CO2/CH4 separation, transient breakthrough experiments were performed in fixed-bed adsorption processes with a 1/1 gas mixture flowing at a rate of 2.0 mL min–1 through a packed column with 0.557 g of as-activated MOF 2. For C2H2/CH4 separation, as shown in a, C2H2 remained in the column longer than CH4 did, with the retention times recorded as 21.6 min g–1 for CH4 and 57.5 min g–1 for C2H2. The dynamic high-purity C2H2 (>99.8%) capture capacity of MOF 2 can reach 1.93 mmol g–1, and that for CH4 0.20 mmol g–1, thus giving a separation factor of 10. Similar results can also be observed for the CO2/CH4 mixture (b); from the column outlet, CH4 was initially detected and quickly approached pure grade (29.9 min g–1), whereas CO2 was captured by the packed samples until breakthrough (37.3 min g–1) with a separation factor of 2. To ensure the excellent cycle performance and easy regeneration of MOF 2, multiple cycling dynamic breakthrough experiments were performed accordingly. In panels c and d of , the C2H2 capture capacities and separation performances demonstrated by cycling experiments remain steady after several cycles, further demonstrating that MOF 2 is a potential adsorbent for C2H2 separation and capture.
